full_title_en: Revised Natural History Model for Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
short_title_en: Revised Natural History Model for PSC
medium_description_en: Estimates survival from primary sclerosing cholangitis.
short_description_en: Estimates survival in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

seo.meta_description_en: The Revised Natural History Model for Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis estimates survival probability of a patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis.
seo.keywords_en: revised natural history sclerosing cholangitis, sclerosing cholangitis score, cholangitis score, cholangitis model, sclerosing cholangitis model, sclerosing model, natural history model cholangitis, cholangitis revise model, sclerosing cholangitis model, cholangitis score, cholangitis calc, sclerosing cholangitis score, sclerosing cholangitis calc

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Revised Natural History Model (Mayo Score) for Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) provides a standardized assessment to help predict survival and transplant need.
  • It does not require require histology or liver biopsy, making it a useful, non-invasive test.
how_to_use.why_use_en: The Revised Natural History Model for PSC is a convenient and simple scoring system.

next_steps.advice_en: The Revised Natural History Model for PSC is a convenient and simple scoring system.
next_steps.management_en: Refer to ACG guidelines for management of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

about.more_info_en:
• Scores ≤0 - low risk group.
  • Scores 0-2 - intermediate risk group.
  • Scores >2 - high risk group.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Kim WR, et. al. A revised natural history model for primary sclerosing cholangitis. Mayo Clinic Proceedings 2000;75:688-694.

Validation.text: Ponsioen CY. Natural history of primary sclerosing cholangitis and prognostic value of cholangiography in a Dutch population. Gut. Oct 2002; 51(4): 562–566.

creator_info.about_en: W. Ray Kim, MD, is the Chief of the Division of Gastroenterology & Hepatology at Stanford University. He formerly studied in Seoul, South Korea, and completed fellowships in gastroenterology and hepatology at the Mayo Clinic.
